Posts.Content: Hi gina, I'm back at work after being in the same place as you last September. Top tip for getting through the wait? Go out! My friends took me to the cinema, theatre, quiz night- anything to take up some hours! It worked for me and I wish you lots of luck. You can manage one day at a time x
Posts.Title: newly diagnosed and terrified.

Posts.Content: Well done everyone through the finishing line. May have to try a cherry b myself- most drinks just taste horrible, but not for much longer!  The arm warming sink is a big sink full of hot water that you put your arm in! You keep it topped up nice and warm, wrap arm in fluffy towel and the needle goes in a treat! Anyone struggling just ask, I would if I'd known!  Enjoy the weekend chemo buddies, I'm going to start browsing for summer holidays even though won't book til after radio, we can dream! X
Posts.Title: Thursday/Friday chemo kitties

Posts.Content: Good luck chemo buddies, had my last fec yesterday yippee! Vicky, welcome to our club, good luck with number too. Each one gets you nearer to the end of it all. Can't believe it's nearly over, just a few weeks more to get through then a nice rest before radio. Hope it all goes well. I was put in the arm warming sink yesterday. Highly recommend it over the warming blanket. Nearly nodded off! Hope all goes well for you all x
Posts.Title: Thursday/Friday chemo kitties

Posts.Content: Good luck peepee and genny, now you are on the roller coaster time will soon zoom by. I can't believe it's my 3rd fec next week and that is half way. Everyone on here is so helpful. I hope all goes well for you. Fec makes my nose and lady bits tingle but not at the same time. My nurse warned me but it was still a bit of a surprise so I warn you too! I'm sure you will both be fine and hope your hospital is like mine and bustling- it was more like being in a branch of Costa than I expected. Having said that I got tearful when it dawned there that this was me- not someone else. Deep breath and remember the sooner it starts the sooner it ends. Good luck, I will be thinking of you both. X
Posts.Title: First FEC Thank You

Posts.Content: Prickly bum? My first chemo nurse described it as fizzy fanny! Said they'd been asked if it was available as a pill! Not by me! X
Posts.Title: prickly bum

Posts.Content: Hi andy, what a kind guy looking for help for his mum. I wasn't given this choice to make I'm afraid, but met with a consultant who had a suggested plan which included both chemo and radio after my lumpectomy. Has your mum just chatted with the nurses? Will she see the oncologist perhaps who might make things clearer? Maybe this option thing does happen frequently, if so someone will be along soon who will know, but I'm glad I didn't have to choose- I'd prefer to be guided by the experts. I hope you get an answer soon and wish you and your mum well x
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy or Chemo??

Posts.Content: Hi ladies, think you are right about 3 being the magic number! I'm 46 and haven't had one since fec 3. Just as well as my lovely 13 year old had her first one Christmas Eve - as my hair was falling out- and she's been having them every 2 to 3 weeks since! I get night sweats now and have to change my pjs, like you I have to whip my hat off in the daytime to let the steam escape! I start tamoxifen in a month. I knew periods might start again but was hoping the tablets would keep the menopause going... Surely doing it twice is just cruel after all we've done already?
Posts.Title: hot flush or just because I am bald

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, not been on in ages as I've returned to work... Not much energy left for much after that! The RNA sharples and other celebrity curly tops comments made me laugh, thank you! I didn't laugh when hubby said my new curls (chemo ended in March) were great: lovely and thick: just like Rory McIlroys hair... No laughter then, just a trip to the hairdressers! She recommended FrizzEase products and they do tame it til about tea time when the Brillo pad look returns. On the plus side it is much darker than what I had before and takes 2 minutes to sort in the mornings. Lovely to read messages from some of my chemo clubbers, love to you all x
Posts.Title: Does anyone have curly chemo hair ?

Posts.Content: Ah, that's brilliant, well done. X
Posts.Title: Hair cut

Posts.Content: Great news, smiling for you x
Posts.Title: In a bubble

Posts.Content: Oh grumpy bum, you sound like you need a big virtual hug. Your lovely child loves you and trusts you so much he can share his frustrations with you. He hates the cancer too and we all hate the side effects, but eventually the treatment will do its job. Give yourself a hug for being tough enough to take this journey, that none of is want to be on, and don't beat yourself up. Cuddle your boy with his honesty, it's not a weakness to give the vibe of hating the cancer, and start again tomorrow. You will get there, you're amazing and doing brilliantly. I bet you get a lot less rest than most of us- mine are at school each day so I can nap, no wonder you're exhaustled. Take care and I'm sure others will be along soon with lovely advice and wisdom. I'm probably rambling as I'm off to bed but couldn't let you not have a reply. You don't have to keep smiling on here, you just keep going. I hope you sleep well, take care x
Posts.Title: grumpy bum

Posts.Content: Hi ctrig, I've not tried the magnets but have had reflexology on my feet- slept like a log afterwards. I didn't think it would do anything, and I don't even wear flip flops as I don't like the thing between my toes, but it was quite pleasant. I've had 2 sessions now and can really recommend it for sleep. I get the sessions at the hospital, no fee, and it might be worth a go if there's something local to you? I never thought I'd sleep through the night again with all this treatment but now have hope ! X
Posts.Title: Today has been a blurrrr

Posts.Content: Yippee! Well done you!! The end is in sight now and you've not only done it but shown us it's possible too, thank you! Xx
Posts.Title: yahooo

Posts.Content: Hi amber, my coping tip is one you've already done; get on this site! I was in your shoes back in October. Since then I've had chemo and radio after my op. This week I started back at work! Take one day at a time is the best advice I read in here. Take any complementary therapies you can get. My hospital gave me reflexology which I didn't think would do much, but boy is it relaxing! You may find another one suits you; I wasn't a fan but it's horses for courses. I tried to do a 15 minute walk each day and get up to see the family out of the door each morning. Some days that was really about it! Accept that you're living in the slow lane for a while. Now I'm trying to get out into the other lanes again it all seems very fast! Another tip I received from someone also in this boat was to not say "what if?"... Tricky but worth trying! I wish you so much luck, keep coming on here, it kept me going. X
Posts.Title: Dreading results

Posts.Content: Ali owl you'll love it! A group of us leave our families behind and ski for a long weekend every year. I've had to cancel because of treatment but hope to go again next year. It is just brilliant fun and with compulsory hot chocolate, brandy, hot tubs and wine! Not sure I want to lie on a tea tray and slide down an icy track tho! Skiing will definitely blow the cobwebs away and let you know you've got through this- get planning! X
Posts.Title: things to do when this is all over

Posts.Content: Hi Ali owl, feeling knackered! Emend stopping most sickness but still feel queasy. Normally can manage cup of tea by Saturday of chemo week but tastes revolting. Feeling ugly as hell. Hubby finds it hard seeing me look so ill. Don't wear my wig as kids hate it but wonder whether to give it a try in the bedroom, if I can stay awake! Hope your meds working and snow didn't stop your footie this weekend. I meant to look and see. Boys in this house are leeds fans so it was all over by mid afternoon. Hope rest of chemo club have had good week x
Posts.Title: how u all doin ?

Posts.Content: So glad it's been a bit better this time. The hot flush is a good one to miss, my face is scarlet! We had snow for a few hours but all gone now in South London. Hope next week is still good for you x
Posts.Title: how u all doin ?

Posts.Content: Hi chemo buddies, just a quick thank you for always being there to rant at and talk to. Was feeling rubbish yesterday but always get picked up by your posts. We took the kids for a pizza today and it felt great to be all out together like the old normal. Feel it is so unfair for them to miss out on stuff but today we had fun, even if I did have to swap and have kids pud while my boy had a grown up size- I just couldn't face it! Might try monkfish next eek though after reading another thread. Thank you all x
Posts.Title: how u all doin ?

Posts.Content: Hi blue roan, my goodness you are busy! I take my hat off to you (no pun intended, I never used to wear them until chemo took my hair) for managing all this nutrition (?) work alongside your chemo. I think though, you might be at risk of worrying many people on here. Boil and cool tap water? Really? Uk water does not need to be boiled. I worry about people beginning this journey believing they need to bath twice a day and bleach their sink before washing a piece of fruit. I know I need to save my energy for worthwhile and recommended activities like going for a walk. I have been told to avoid alcohol, deep fried food and dark chocolate as my liver is struggling with the chemo and yet you are recommending dark chocolate. I will stick to my crunchie bar and the odd twix. We are all on different regimes and we are all individuals. I come here  to offer and receive support. Thanks but no thanks from me for your nutrition advice. Hope I haven't been harsh. Bad day. Infection and almost admitted with neutropenia today but nothing I have read on here has ever made me want to rant so much. I wish you well.
Posts.Title: New - My experience so far. Will it help you? Stage 2 + lymph; HER2...

Posts.Content: Hi stoatie, you poor thing. The thought of chemo is horrid, but it IS doable and you will manage whatever this wretched disease throws at you. TTwo out of three notes is better than three out of three- they've got it out and now the treatment is to stop it coming back. Keep coming on, you know this lovely community is here to support you. We know the pain and the worries that wake you in the night. A big hug to you x
Posts.Title: New - My experience so far. Will it help you? Stage 2 + lymph; HER2...

Posts.Content: Hi Ali owl, thanks. Yes it does get you down but I usually manage a positive face so the kids believe mum is on the mend. Thanks Monica, yes I agree with some of blue roan too, but didn't actually make reference to that. Don't fancy going looking for the untame forums!!! Have only got energy this morning for phil schofield! x
Posts.Title: New - My experience so far. Will it help you? Stage 2 + lymph; HER2...

Posts.Content: Think you could get more than Philip schofield if you google it! Watched it and the 3 ladies seemed very happy with their steaming and the mixture that got painted on...
Posts.Title: New - My experience so far. Will it help you? Stage 2 + lymph; HER2...

Posts.Content: Many apologies ladies. I should have just read the post and moved on. I'm feeling the worst I have felt in all chemo. Number 3 worse than 1 and 2. In my 'normal' life, before all this I would not have written to challenge your ideas, I would just peacefully live and let live. Perhaps reading all your ideas, while feeling so horrible was just too much. Of course we all just do what we need to do to get through. I'd hate it if reading my post made you feel as I felt after reading your response to me. I'm feeling particularly vulnerable, worried and fed up with this whole thing of surgery, drugs, chemo and now antibiotics and generally, as I think most of my post show, try to be positive and helpful. Please allow me to apologise and draw a line under the whole thing. I think I might avoid any responses to anyone now as my judgement and word choices have obviously been affected by chemo.  Once again, sorry for making any response to your post about your blog, I should have just moved on .  Mx
Posts.Title: New - My experience so far. Will it help you? Stage 2 + lymph; HER2...

Posts.Content: Sandy sorry you feel so sad. this is just the most normal reaction. We have all been there and still are. The bursting into tears, the disbelief, the frustration is all normal. Sorry to welcome you to our club here that this time last year we had no idea we'd join. I was diagnosed in October too and have found reading everyone's posts so useful. Each day I am reminded that what I feel is shared by others and it's normal. Annoying, Read the other posts too and reassure yourself. You are SO normal and I wish you so much luck and love getting through it, but get through you will x
Posts.Title: How should i be feeling??????

Posts.Content: Brilliant news! What a difference a year makes, love to all you fab chemo clubbers who helped us get this far and still be smiling.
Posts.Title: 1st year mammogram

Posts.Content: Hi Roseiro, yep, mine started to go a bit at 14 but it got much more rapid around 17. It can get tingly before it goes, I wish I had gone even shorter than I had as the length of the hair is quite heavy when it comes out and it did hurt a bit. I tried to think of it as evidence that the drugs were working, but won't lie- it's horrible. On the plus side no leg shaving, armpit care, lady garden tidying to do! After 4 fec I still have eyebrows- in the same shape as at the beginning but a little thinner. So some advantages! It is quicker to get up and out just by flinging a hat on. You will get through this, good luck x
Posts.Title: Hair Care before and after Chemo

Posts.Content: Hi maggie, it definitely exists! I finished chemo 6 weeks ago and am just getting my vocabulary back, I couldn't find words I wanted which was frustrating! I found I could manage only one task at a time- even more annoying! I played scramble online with my daughter and others and this week I won my first game since December- which I put down to chemo. Definite evidence in my book! I'm hoping to start reading books again as I found I got confused if there were more than 3 characters. I'm sure people have other experiences of the effects if chemo fog, but for me the worst bit is that cloud which stops you from feeling like you. Rest assured, it will lift once they stop pumping in the drugs. Good luck, you're not going mad, just take it easy and you'll get there x
Posts.Title: chemo fog

Posts.Content: Hope waiting and chemo ok for Thursday chemo clubbers. This Wednesday clubber had no 5 of 6 yesterday.normally only a couple of hours but poor veins are shot to pieces so it took 4 people to have a go each then poor lady in the room had an allergic reaction. Thankfully mild and she continued treatment. Not the usual smooth experience, but only 1 to go. Great day earlier in week though. Look good feel better afternoon was great. If you're thinking about going then do it! Met nice people in the same boat and came home with fantastic goodie bag of branded cosmetics and perfume. Great top tips for creating eyebrows and I had a lovely time.big hugs to all of you with chemo today and tomorrow. Rest up and keep counting down- we're doing it!! Xx
Posts.Title: Thursday/ Friday chemo club

Posts.Content: You poor thing that sounds awful. Sleep well tonight and think it's another step closer. Those beasties are being zapped it's just a shame it makes us feel so cr** but at least that means it's doing the job. You'll be making those lovely dinners again soon and cheering on your team with the loudest voice in the stadium. Goodnight all x
Posts.Title: Thursday/ Friday chemo club

Posts.Content: I don't call that an epic fail- sounds like epic bravery to me. Pretty certain I couldn't do it. Good luck x
Posts.Title: Epic fail lol

Posts.Content: Hi Sarah, I'm coming up for my 2 year check soon, also breast cancer and my children were 13 and 7. I can only agree with what others have said. Honesty and openness helped, and the medikidz carton book was the one my son returned to again and again- he's the youngest. I read it first and we used the language in it to explain everything. My daughter liked this book http://www.eekmymummy.co.uk/  and still looks at it now. They got to watch lots of films- with me nodding off on the sofa during chemo, I recommend bulk cooking so you can freeze spares for days you don't feel like it, and we discovered some great friends and some others who actually weren't up for it. Accept any help that's offered too- people like to be useful! My son didn't like the wig so I didn't wear one as he thought it felt 'freaky'. They will look at my scar when we are changing for swimming or I'm getting dressed and I truly cannot believe now that it was our family that it happened too.  I wish you lots of luck, take one day at a time and enjoy all the extra cuddles. Mx
Posts.Title: Stage 3 breast cancer help & how to tell my children
